messageBody:
This is constructive criticism. Please accept it that way. There are several issues with your code, in addition to answering your original question.

1. Your comments are useless and actually dangerous. I say this with love. Stop writing silly comments when the code says exactly what it does already.

EXAMPLE:
> // This member variable will hold account balance
> public int balance;

The following is already clear enough.

> public int balance;

You may ask why this matters. Here is why. In your code you have:

>public class Interest extends Account {
>
> // This member variable will hold account balance
> private int interest_rate;
> private int acumulated_interest;

THAT COMMENT IS WRONG!

You have just demonstrated the reason why unnecessary comments are not just unnecessary, they are DANGEROUS: your comment and code do not match. Three months from now, which one should you trust? At a minimum, you need to read the code to find out.

Stop doing this immediately. You will find life much nicer.

2. Use better names.

"JU" means nothing to anyone, except maybe yourself. I renamed the test case classes to "AccountTest" and "InterestTest", because THAT IS WHAT THEY ARE!

3. Don't leave empty tests.

You have an empty test in AccountTest. That test LOOKS like it passes, but only because there is nothing to fail. I replaced it with "fail("Not yet implemented.")".

4. One of your tests doesn't make sense.

deposit() answers the new balance, but withdraw() answers the amount withdrawn. Why have this strange behavior?

public void testwithdraw2() {
assertEquals(myAccount.withdraw(4000), 4000);
} //End of method

I changed this test to read

public void testwithdraw2() {
assertEquals(myAccount.withdraw(4000), 6000);
}

because this behavior makes much more sense, compared with the behavior of deposit().

I ran AccountTest. Of the three tests that you implemented, two passed, so I fixed withdraw() to behave the same way as deposit().

I then ran InterestTest. Of the five tests that you implemented, they all pass.

Since you got the inheritance stuff right, what's the problem?

>So said balakrishnan sengodan on 4/13/2003 --------------------
>Did any one test inheritance successfully, will you
>please send me the classes under the test and the
>associated testing classes.
<snip />
